lg.l: A man with expence & Infinite toyle
By planting & dunging enobled his soyle
Where fruits of the best his tast did invite
And Uniform Order still courted the sight
No Degenerate Weed ye rich Ground did produce
But all things afforded for beauty & use
Till from dunghill transplanted (while yet but a seed)
A Nettle rear'd up his inglorious head
The Gardener wou'd wisely have rooted him up
To stop the increase of a barbarous Crop
But the Master forbid him, & after ye fashion
Of foolish good nature, & blind Moderation
For·bore him thrô pitty, & chose ye much rather
To ask him some questions; first how he came thither?
Kind Sr (quoth the Nettle) a Stranger I come
A Wanderer thrô Conscience, I relinquish my home
Cause I wou'd not subscribe to a Mistery dark
That the N···· of all Tree's was ye Jesuits Bark
An Erronious Tenet I know Sr that You,
No more then my self will allow to be true?
To you I for Refuge & Sanctu'ry sue,
Theres none so Renoun'd for Compassion as you.
And tho' in some things I may differ from these
The rest of your fruitfull & beautifull Trees
As your digging & dunging my nature much harms
And I cannot comply with yur Garden in forms
Yet I & my Family after our fashion
Will peacibly stick to our own Education.
Be pleas'd to allow us a place for to rest in
For the rest of your Tree's wee'l never molest 'em.
A kind shelter to me, & Protection afford
We'll do you no harm Sr I'le give you my word
The Good man was soon mov'd wth a plausible Tale,
[So fraud on good Nature too of't does prevaile)
He welcomes his Guest gives him free Toleration
In the midst of his Garden to take up his Station
And into his Bosom does his Enemy bring
He little suspected, the Nettle cou'd sting
Till flush'd with success & of strength to be fear'd
Around him a numerous offspring he rear'd.
Then ye Master grew sensible what he had done
And feign wou'd have had his new guest to be gone
But now t'was too late to bid him turn out
A well rooted possession allready was got
The old Tree's decay'd & in their room grew
A stubborn Rank pestilent Poys'nous Crew
The Master who first ye young brood had admitted
They stung like ungrates & left him unpitty'd
No help from Manureing or planting were found
The weeds had eat up the heart of the Ground
Now all Weeds are let in, & none they refuse
That wou'd join to oppose the good Man of ye house
Thus One Nettle uncropt increas'd to such store
That t'was nothing but weeds, what was Garden before.X85-632L
